column1: I’m the mom here. I live with my husband
column3: and our daughter (F21). A recurring issue between my daughter and me is “hanging out.” She says we already spend time together because we share space
column6: or do a puzzle or art sometimes. I appreciate those moments
column7: but they’re either chores or things we’re already doing at home. What I keep asking for is intentional

column1: Today there was a local boat race. I asked her to come with me
column2: she said no. I didn’t go after that because the point was to do it with her
column3: not stand there alone. I told her I’m frustrated because this isn’t a one-off. When I invite her to my things
column6: but how about Saturday?” or an alternative. Now she says I’m guilt-tripping her and that she doesn’t “owe” me time because we see each other every day.

column1: I’m not trying to collect a debt. I’m asking for reciprocity. She’s an adult living at home
column2: benefiting from the stability and support we provide. Part of living together is compromise and sometimes doing an activity you wouldn’t pick because it matters to someone you love. Proximity isn’t the same as quality time. When the answer is almost always no to my invitations
column3: it reads as “your interests don’t matter.” If she had counter-offered
column4: I’d have gladly gone another day.

column3: and I think she’s at fault here. Saying no occasionally is fine; saying no by default
column5: and then calling my disappointment “guilt-tripping” is unkind. Relationships need give-and-take
